I gat an error when trying to compress code containing constants:
"JSC_PARSE_ERROR: Parse error. Unsupported syntax: CONST at line 254 
character 0
const I8 = 8;"

A hacky patch attached that fixes this for existing code (assumes const is var).

Obviously it'd be cool if const-ness checked but this should get your code compiled
at least.

In general, closure compiler emits errors for code that it can tell won't work on all 
browsers. (const doesn't work on IE).

We've talked about supporting const, but were worried that would just make the problem 
worse. A large part of the benefit of the compiler is that it guarantees all browsers 
will parse your code correctly.

I get value out of the compiler's current (strict) behavior.  If syntax that isn't valid in all 
browsers is supported, my vote would be for a flag that would check to ensure the 
syntax was valid for all (major) browsers.
Issue 82 has been merged into this issue.

Why does it matter if the input to the compiler contains the 'const' kewyord? For cross-brwoser compatibility, the closure compiler would just have to make sure that 'const' doesn't appear in the _output_, no?
There is an option to accept const but to treat it as var. I dont encourage this though as in ecmascript 6 const is lexically scoped like let ( also in es6) but unlike var
